questions.theme: NRR structural decline despite AI momentum
questions.question: Sridhar, I want to revisit a concern that's come up on every call for the past three years: NRR has now declined for 13 consecutive quarters, hitting a company-record low of 125% this quarter, down from 127% a year ago. You've crossed $100 million in AI revenue run rate, you've launched Snowflake Intelligence, Cortex AI adoption is accelerating with over 3,200 accounts — yet the expansion rate continues to deteriorate. Your 10-Q explicitly flags risk around customers' ability to 'maintain and increase consumption on your platform.' At what point should investors conclude that AI workloads are incremental but fundamentally insufficient to offset the structural compression in your core data warehousing expansion rates? And can you give us a specific timeline for when you expect NRR to stabilize or inflect?
questions.data_basis: NRR trend data showing 13 consecutive quarters of decline from 178% to 125% [Section B]; $100M+ AI revenue milestone and 3,200+ Cortex AI accounts [Section F historical questions]; 10-Q risk disclosure on consumption maintenance [Section I]; recurring analyst questions from Kash Rangan and others specifically challenging why NRR isn't improving despite new products [Section F Q1 FY2026]; Wells Fargo survey showing customers expect only 0-10% q/q increases [Section H]

questions.question: You just announced the SAP Business Data Cloud partnership on November 4th, which follows Databricks' own SAP partnership that Kirk Materne specifically asked about last quarter. At the same time, you're partnering with Palantir, who is arguably a competitor in enterprise analytics. Microsoft Fabric continues to grow with Azure at 33%, and your own 10-Q acknowledges you operate in a 'very competitive and rapidly changing environment.' Help me understand the strategic logic here: are these partnerships an admission that you can't win these enterprise data workloads on your own? And specifically on SAP, given Databricks got there first, what's the incremental value proposition for a joint SAP-Snowflake customer versus what Databricks already offers?
questions.data_basis: SAP partnership announcement November 4, 2025 [Section G]; Palantir partnership October 16, 2025 [Section G]; Kirk Materne's Q4 FY2025 question about competitor partnering with SAP [Section F]; Microsoft Azure growth at 33% [Section C]; 10-Q competitive risk language [Section I]; Jefferies survey noting competitive dynamics as key debate [Section H]

questions.theme: Sales investment ROI and margin trajectory
questions.question: Brian, welcome to your first call as CFO. I want to address the elephant in the room on capital allocation. You've had the largest six-month sales hiring spree in company history — Mark Murphy highlighted this last quarter — yet operating margin ticked down this quarter on that sales and marketing investment, and Brad Reback asked directly about balancing opportunity versus margin expansion. RPO grew only 21% year-over-year versus product revenue at 29%, which suggests bookings momentum may be lagging your hiring pace. With 688 customers now spending over $1 million, up 27% year-over-year, but NRR at historic lows, can you quantify the expected payback period on this sales investment? And should we expect operating margins to remain under pressure through fiscal 2027 as you absorb this capacity?
questions.data_basis: RPO growth of 21.1% vs product revenue growth of 28.8% [Section A]; $1M+ customers at 688 up 26.9% YoY [Section A]; Brad Reback's Q3 FY2026 question on margin vs. opportunity tradeoff [Section F]; Mark Murphy's Q2 FY2026 question on 'enormous' sales hiring [Section F]; Mike Cikos noting operating margin down-tick [Section F Q3 FY2026]; FCF growth of 41.3% suggests some leverage but margin concern persists

question.theme: NRR structural decline despite AI momentum
question.question: Sridhar, I want to revisit a concern that's come up on every call for the past three years: NRR has now declined for 13 consecutive quarters, hitting a company-record low of 125% this quarter, down from 127% a year ago. You've crossed $100 million in AI revenue run rate, you've launched Snowflake Intelligence, Cortex AI adoption is accelerating with over 3,200 accounts — yet the expansion rate continues to deteriorate. Your 10-Q explicitly flags risk around customers' ability to 'maintain and increase consumption on your platform.' At what point should investors conclude that AI workloads are incremental but fundamentally insufficient to offset the structural compression in your core data warehousing expansion rates? And can you give us a specific timeline for when you expect NRR to stabilize or inflect?
question.data_basis: NRR trend data showing 13 consecutive quarters of decline from 178% to 125% [Section B]; $100M+ AI revenue milestone and 3,200+ Cortex AI accounts [Section F historical questions]; 10-Q risk disclosure on consumption maintenance [Section I]; recurring analyst questions from Kash Rangan and others specifically challenging why NRR isn't improving despite new products [Section F Q1 FY2026]; Wells Fargo survey showing customers expect only 0-10% q/q increases [Section H]

qa_pairs.response: Thank you for the direct question. You're right that NRR at 125% represents continued compression, and I won't sugarcoat that — it reflects the natural maturation of our largest cohorts and the optimization behaviors we've seen industry-wide. However, I'd push back on the characterization that AI is insufficient: we crossed $100 million in AI revenue run rate a quarter ahead of schedule, we added 146 customers spending over $1 million this year alone — that's 27% growth — and our RPO of $6.9 billion, up 21%, signals strong forward commitment. What gives me confidence is that NRR is a trailing indicator while our leading indicators — 3,200-plus Cortex accounts, four nine-figure deals this quarter, and 29% product revenue growth — are inflecting positively. We expect NRR to stabilize in the first half of fiscal 2027 as these AI workloads scale and our newer products like Snowflake Intelligence move from adoption to meaningful consumption.

question.question: You just announced the SAP Business Data Cloud partnership on November 4th, which follows Databricks' own SAP partnership that Kirk Materne specifically asked about last quarter. At the same time, you're partnering with Palantir, who is arguably a competitor in enterprise analytics. Microsoft Fabric continues to grow with Azure at 33%, and your own 10-Q acknowledges you operate in a 'very competitive and rapidly changing environment.' Help me understand the strategic logic here: are these partnerships an admission that you can't win these enterprise data workloads on your own? And specifically on SAP, given Databricks got there first, what's the incremental value proposition for a joint SAP-Snowflake customer versus what Databricks already offers?
question.data_basis: SAP partnership announcement November 4, 2025 [Section G]; Palantir partnership October 16, 2025 [Section G]; Kirk Materne's Q4 FY2025 question about competitor partnering with SAP [Section F]; Microsoft Azure growth at 33% [Section C]; 10-Q competitive risk language [Section I]; Jefferies survey noting competitive dynamics as key debate [Section H]

qa_pairs.response: Let me be direct with you - these partnerships aren't an admission of weakness, they're a recognition that enterprise data is fragmented across dozens of systems, and customers are demanding interoperability. Our SAP partnership announced November 4th brings Snowflake's AI Data Cloud directly into SAP's Business Data Fabric with native integration and zero-copy data sharing - the incremental value versus alternatives is that SAP customers can leverage our Cortex AI capabilities, including our Anthropic partnership, directly on their enterprise data without extraction or duplication. The proof is in our execution: we just delivered $1.16 billion in product revenue, up 29% year-over-year, added 146 customers spending over $1 million, and crossed $100 million in AI revenue run rate - that's not the profile of a company that can't compete. On Palantir, they bring deep vertical expertise in defense and government that complements our platform strengths, and this quarter alone we signed four nine-figure deals, so clearly enterprises see us as the center of gravity for their data workloads regardless of which analytics tools sit on top.

question.theme: Sales investment ROI and margin trajectory
question.question: Brian, welcome to your first call as CFO. I want to address the elephant in the room on capital allocation. You've had the largest six-month sales hiring spree in company history — Mark Murphy highlighted this last quarter — yet operating margin ticked down this quarter on that sales and marketing investment, and Brad Reback asked directly about balancing opportunity versus margin expansion. RPO grew only 21% year-over-year versus product revenue at 29%, which suggests bookings momentum may be lagging your hiring pace. With 688 customers now spending over $1 million, up 27% year-over-year, but NRR at historic lows, can you quantify the expected payback period on this sales investment? And should we expect operating margins to remain under pressure through fiscal 2027 as you absorb this capacity?
question.data_basis: RPO growth of 21.1% vs product revenue growth of 28.8% [Section A]; $1M+ customers at 688 up 26.9% YoY [Section A]; Brad Reback's Q3 FY2026 question on margin vs. opportunity tradeoff [Section F]; Mark Murphy's Q2 FY2026 question on 'enormous' sales hiring [Section F]; Mike Cikos noting operating margin down-tick [Section F Q3 FY2026]; FCF growth of 41.3% suggests some leverage but margin concern persists

qa_pairs.response: Thank you for the warm welcome, and it's a fair question to tackle head-on. You're right that we've made significant sales investments, and yes, operating margin ticked down this quarter as a result — that's a deliberate trade-off we're making given the AI opportunity in front of us. On the RPO versus product revenue dynamic, I'd note that our consumption model means revenue recognition often runs ahead of bookings cycles, and we actually added four nine-figure deals this quarter with strong customer commitment. Regarding payback periods, we're targeting 12 to 18 months for new sales capacity, and the early cohorts from our H1 hiring are already contributing — our 688 million-dollar customers growing 27% year-over-year reflects that productivity. On NRR at 125%, I won't sugarcoat it — that's our lowest, but it's stabilizing, and importantly, our newer products like Cortex AI, now at $100 million-plus run rate, aren't yet fully reflected in that trailing metric. For fiscal 2027, we expect some near-term margin pressure as this capacity absorbs, but we have line of sight to operating leverage as these investments mature and AI workloads scale.
